ARTS-5849.courseDescription: is an introduction to the work of major authors by detailed study of selected texts. There is an emphasis on the various skills of essay writing. Some sections of this course may qualify as Research/Writing courses for the B.A.

ARTS-5848.courseDescription: is an examination of prose texts such as essays, articles and reviews. Students write for different purposes and audiences. Emphasis is placed on critical reading and writing: analysing texts, framing and using questions, constructing essays, organizing paragraphs, conducting research, quoting and documenting, revising and editing.
ARTS-5848.courseTitle: Critical Reading and Writing II (Context, Substance, Style)
ARTS-5848.CR: ENGL 1020 , ENGL 1030 . Students may not receive credit for more than 6 credit hours in first-year courses in English (this includes unspecified first-year transfer credits).

ARTS-5948.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5948.courseDescription: is a study of late eighteenth- and early nineteenth-century texts in their social, political, and cultural contexts, with particular focus on the first generation of Romantic writers.

ARTS-5949.courseDescription: is a study of late eighteenth- and early nineteenth-century texts in their social, political, and cultural contexts, with particular focus on the second generation of Romantic writers.

ARTS-5944.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5944.courseDescription: focuses on the prose and poetry of representative authors of the period and provides a critical overview of the literary, historical, social, political, and religious context.

ARTS-5946.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5946.courseDescription: is a study of selected works by such authors as Dryden, Swift, Pope, Fielding, and Lady Mary Wortley Montagu.
ARTS-5946.courseTitle: Restoration and Early Eighteenth-Century British Literature

ARTS-5947.courseDescription: is a study of selected works by such authors as Boswell, Burney, Johnson, Smollett, and Sterne.

ARTS-5940.courseDescription: permits students to analyse and practice reviewing of three kinds: (a) performance; (b) film, TV, video; c) books.

ARTS-5941.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5941.courseDescription: is a study of European thought and culture as they affect the history and development of English literature from the Middle Ages to the eighteenth century.
ARTS-5941.courseTitle: English Literature and History of Ideas I

ARTS-5942.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5942.courseDescription: is a study of European thought and culture as they affect the history and development of English literature from the eighteenth century to the present.
ARTS-5942.courseTitle: English Literature and the History of Ideas II

ARTS-5943.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5943.courseDescription: focuses on the prose and poetry of representative authors of the period and provides a critical overview of the literary, historical, social, political, and religious context.

ARTS-5951.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5951.courseDescription: is a study of selected works by such writers as Thackeray, Gaskell, George Eliot, Arnold, and the Rossettis.

ARTS-5950.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5950.courseDescription: is a study of selected works by such writers as Carlyle, Dickens, Tennyson, the Brownings, and the Brontës.

ARTS-5931.PR: Normally, admission to this course will be based on the instructor's evaluation of the student's writing. Class size will be limited.
ARTS-5931.courseDescription: is conducted as a seminar using models of contemporary writing and the students' own work. Each student will be required to submit work regularly.
ARTS-5931.CR: credit may be obtained for only two of ENGL 3900, 3901 , and 3905

ARTS-5930.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5930.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.

ARTS-5933.PR: the regular prerequisites for 3000-level offerings, plus submission of a portfolio specified by the instructor and permission of the instructor
ARTS-5933.courseDescription: is conducted as a seminar using models of contemporary dramatic writing and the students’ own work. Each student will be required to submit work regularly.

ARTS-5932.PR: Normally, admission to this course will be based on the instructor's evaluation of the student's writing. Class size will be limited.
ARTS-5932.courseDescription: is conducted as a seminar using models of contemporary writing and the students' own work. Each student will be required to submit work regularly.
ARTS-5932.CR: credit may be obtained for only two of ENGL 3900 , 3901, and 3905

ARTS-5935.courseDescription: will permit students to learn to draft and edit short investigative pieces; and they complete an article or essay, and an investigative project that attends to ethics guidelines, research, documentation, interviewing protocols, and writing and editing for a specific context. The course is conducted as a seminar using the students’ own work. Each student will be required to submit work regularly. Some work may be done collaboratively.

ARTS-5934.PR: the regular prerequisites for 3000-level offerings, plus submission of a portfolio specified by the instructor and permission of the instructor
ARTS-5934.courseDescription: is conducted as a seminar using models of contemporary writing and the students’ own work. Each student will be required to submit work regularly.

ARTS-5937.courseDescription: uses models from early ballads to contemporary hits and near-misses as a basis for students’ own work. Guest songwriters will be invited to meet with students to discuss their compositions. Students will analyse song lyrics, write their own songs and collaborate on a major class project. The ability to sing or play a musical instrument or to read or write sheet music, while desirable, is not required.

ARTS-5936.courseDescription: uses models of contemporary satire as a basis for students’ own work. Guest satirists will be invited to meet with students who will write satirical sketches, articles and/or plays based on their own experiences in response to current affairs and topical items of interest. Students will engage in at least one collaborative project.

ARTS-5838.courseDescription: is a non-credit course designed for students whose first language is other than English and whose knowledge and use of English do not meet the standards for entry into the regular first-year English courses.
ARTS-5838.LC: 4 hours of lecture plus one hour conversation class

ARTS-5845.courseDescription: is a study of such forms as the novel, the novella, the story sequence. Emphasis is placed on critical reading and writing: analysing texts, framing and using questions, constructing essays, organizing paragraphs, conducting research, quoting and documenting, revising and editing.
ARTS-5845.CR: Students may not receive credit for more than 6 credit hours in first-year courses in English (this includes unspecified first-year transfer credits).

ARTS-5844.courseDescription: is an introduction to such literary forms as poetry, short fiction, drama, and the essay. Emphasis is placed on critical reading and writing: analysing texts, framing and using questions, constructing essays, organizing paragraphs, quoting and documenting, revising and editing.
ARTS-5844.CR: ENGL 1000 . Students may not receive credit for more than 6 credit hours in first-year courses in English (this includes unspecified first-year transfer credits).

ARTS-5847.courseDescription: is a study of poetry. Emphasis is placed on critical reading and writing: analysing texts, framing and using questions, constructing essays, organizing paragraphs, conducting research, quoting and documenting, revising and editing.
ARTS-5847.CR: Students may not receive credit for more than 6 credit hours in first-year courses in English (this includes unspecified first-year transfer credits).

ARTS-5929.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5929.courseDescription: is a course setting women writers in the context of literary history.

ARTS-5841.courseDescription: develops skills in critical reading and writing of academic English, with emphasis on research and writing syntheses from sources, for non-native English-speaking students.
ARTS-5841.courseTitle: Writing for Second Language Students II
ARTS-5841.CR: Students may not receive credit for more than 6 credit hours in first-year courses in English (this includes unspecified first-year transfer credits).

ARTS-5840.PR: Admission to this course will be determined on the basis of the departmental English Placement Test or successful completion of ENGL 102F .
ARTS-5840.courseDescription: is an introduction to the use of English with emphasis on composition for non-native English-speaking students. This course is for students whose first language is not English and who have passed
ARTS-5840.courseTitle: Writing for Second Language Students I
ARTS-5840.CR: English 1030 , ENGL 1110 . Students may not receive credit for more than 6 credit hours in first-year courses in English (this includes unspecified first-year transfer credits).

ARTS-5922.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5922.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.

ARTS-5921.courseDescription: is available only as part of the

ARTS-5926.PR: ENGL 3350 and 3351 ; admission priority will be given to students in Diploma in Performance and Communications Media .
ARTS-5926.courseDescription: is an introduction to the principles of acting for the camera through lecture, discussion and studio work.

ARTS-5927.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5927.courseDescription: draws on a variety of writing to examine questions related to the study of gender. Possible topics may include the changing constructions of gender and the intersections of gender with race, class, nationality and sexuality. This course may qualify as a research and writing course for the B.A.

ARTS-5924.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5924.courseDescription: is an introduction to the fundamentals and vocabulary of design, lighting and stagecraft and film/ video craft, including sound, properties, etc.
ARTS-5924.courseTitle: The Physical Stage and Video Technique

ARTS-7487.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.
ARTS-7487.courseTitle: Special Topics in Medieval Language and Literature

ARTS-7486.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.

ARTS-7485.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.

ARTS-5997.PR: completion of the six courses in the program, with an overall average of 65% in these courses.
ARTS-5997.courseDescription: is a 6 credit hour course which has students, upon completion of the courses in the
ARTS-5997.courseTitle: Instructional Field Placement in Professional Writing
ARTS-5997.UL: can be used for credit towards the Diploma in Professional Writing

ARTS-5995.PR: ENGL 3350 , 3351 , 3816 , 4400 , 4401 , 4402 , with an overall average of 65% in these courses. Restricted to students in the Diploma in Performance and Communications Media . Admission is by application to the Program Co-ordinator, normally at least three months before the beginning of the placement, and is limited to students who at the time of admission have completed the six courses listed above with an overall average of at least 65% and who already hold a first degree or are in their final year of a degree program as confirmed by the Office of the Registrar.
ARTS-5995.courseDescription: is a 6 credit hour course which occurs upon completion of course work in the
ARTS-5995.UL: can be used for credit only towards the Diploma in Performance and Communications Media

ARTS-5994.courseDescription: is required as part of the Honours program.

ARTS-5993.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5993.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.

ARTS-5992.PR: Normally, students will (a) be enrolled in the Diploma in Professional Writing and (b) have successfully completed at least two of the following: ENGL 3001 , 3817 , 3903 (or other course designated Creative Writing), 3910 , 3920 . Normally, admission to this course will be based on the instructor’s evaluation of the student’s writing. Class size will be limited.
ARTS-5992.courseDescription: is editing for the workplace: An intensive course in drafting and editing. Students will be expected to work both individually and collaboratively.

ARTS-5991.PR: successful completion of at least one Creative Writing course at the 3000-level, plus submission of a portfolio specified by the instructor and permission of the instructor
ARTS-5991.courseDescription: is conducted as a seminar using models of contemporary writing and the students’ own work. Each student will be required to submit work regularly.

ARTS-5856.courseTitle: Comprehension, Writing and Prose Style II

ARTS-5854.courseDescription: requires students to analyze published essays for their aims, strategies, and discourses. Students practice writing as a process of discovery in the context of a learning community: for instance identifying questions to explore, free-writing, finding a focus, drafting, peer-editing, revising, editing. Each student produces a portfolio of revised, edited work. This course qualifies as a Research/Writing Course.

ARTS-5855.UL: cannot be taken for credit by students enrolled in the Bachelor of Music program

ARTS-5852.courseDescription: is a study of poetry, which aims to increase the students critical understanding and appreciation of poetry, conducted through an examination of a wide variety of kinds and techniques.

ARTS-5853.courseDescription: is a study of short fiction which aims to give the students an appreciation of the short story as a literary form. The course will deal with the nature, history and development of short fiction by considering a variety of authors and stories.

ARTS-5850.courseDescription: is an introduction to the work of major authors by detailed study of selected texts. There is an emphasis on the various skills of essay writing. Some sections of this course may qualify as Research/Writing courses for the B.A.

ARTS-5918.courseTitle: Structure of Modern English: Phonology and Morphology

ARTS-5917.courseDescription: is a study of representative poems.

ARTS-5915.PR: successful completion of two 2000-level English courses
ARTS-5915.courseDescription: introduces students to the basic elements of Old English grammar and vocabulary through the practice of translating one or more texts from Old English into modern English and the study of the Old English corpus in modern translations.
ARTS-5915.courseTitle: Introduction to Old English Language and Literature

ARTS-5914.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5914.CR: Folklore 3460 , the former ENGL 4450, and the former Folklore 4450

ARTS-5913.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5913.courseDescription: is an introduction to principles of directing and acting, through lectures, discussion and stage production.

ARTS-5910.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5910.courseDescription: is a study of works by dramatists from a range of periods.

ARTS-5958.courseDescription: is an advanced course focusing on such plays as

ARTS-5988.PR: completion of ENGL 3900 with a grade of 70 or higher and submission of a portfolio and permission of the instructor.
ARTS-5988.courseDescription: is a seminar for students who wish to write publishable literary fiction. Class size will be limited. Students will be expected to produce at least 15,000 words during the semester. Regular participation is also required.

ARTS-5989.PR: normally, admission to this course will be based on the instructor's evaluation of the student's writing and on the achievement of a minimum grade of 70% in ENGL 3901 or ENGL 3900
ARTS-5989.courseDescription: uses models of contemporary writing and the students' own work. This course is designed to develop further the technical skill of those students who have reached a high level of achievement in the introductory creative writing course in poetry, English 3901 (or who have a body of work of exceptional accomplishment) and to help them move towards publication in literary journals and chapbooks.

ARTS-5980.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5980.courseDescription: is a study of representative literary utopias and dystopias, both classic and modern.

ARTS-5981.PR: completion of 3 credit hours chosen from courses at the 2000 or 3000 level in Canadian Literature, or permission of the instructor
ARTS-5981.courseDescription: is a study of some of the main concepts in Canadian culture up to World War II as they affect the history and development of Canadian Literature.

ARTS-5982.PR: completion of 3 credit hours chosen from courses at the 2000 or 3000 level in Canadian Literature, or permission of the instructor
ARTS-5982.courseDescription: is a study of some of the main concepts in Canadian culture since World War II as they affect the history and development of Canadian Literature.

ARTS-5983.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5983.courseDescription: is a seminar course in contemporary Canadian poetry. Students will have the opportunity to study collections by six English Canadian contemporary poets - not just new work by established older writers, but also first collections by younger writers. The work of poets from across Canada will be chosen.

ARTS-5984.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5984.courseDescription: will examine Canada’s early exploration and travel literature and show how it has shaped our contemporary fiction. Early texts may be studied from an anthology of exploration writings, such as Germaine Warkentin's Canadian Exploration Literature: An Anthology. Several contemporary novels will also be studied and may include Wayne Johnston's The Navigator of New York and John Steffler's The Afterlife of George Cartwright.

ARTS-5985.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5985.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.

ARTS-5986.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5986.courseDescription: is an introduction to bibliographical and textual studies to 1800. Areas covered may include the book as a material object; the history of the book; manuscripts; the spread of printing; the hand-press period; editing of texts; the evolution of the library; origins of intellectual property; freedom of the press; aspects of literary detection, forgery and plagiarism.
ARTS-5986.courseTitle: Book History and Print Culture I

ARTS-5987.courseDescription: is an introduction to bibliographical and textual studies from 1800 to the present day. Areas covered may include the book as a material object; the history of the book; machine-press period; industrialization of printing; globalization of the book trade; intellectual property and copyright; electronic book; digital literacy; digital literatures.
ARTS-5987.courseTitle: Book History and Print Culture II

ARTS-5869.courseDescription: is a study of representative American novels of the twentieth century, including such authors as James, Dreiser, Fitzgerald, Hemingway, Faulkner, Hurston, Morrison, Pynchon, DeLillo and Silko.

ARTS-5868.courseDescription: is a survey of representative texts from 1900-2000.

ARTS-5863.courseDescription: introduces students to the significant body of contemporary literature written in English that stands outside the dominant British/North American canon. Authors addressed include writers of global significance such as Achebe, Rushdie, Coetzee, Walcott, Kincaid and Desai. Some sections of this course may qualify as Research/Writing courses for the B.A.
ARTS-5863.courseTitle: Introduction to World Literature in English

ARTS-5867.courseDescription: is a survey of representative texts from 1800-1900. Some sections of this course may qualify as Research/Writing courses for the B.A.

ARTS-5866.courseDescription: will introduce Aboriginal literature in a social, political and historical context. Beginning with the oral tradition (songs, narratives, legends, and orations), it will focus on different works by North American Aboriginal writers: poetry, drama, short stories and novels.

ARTS-5865.courseDescription: is a study of fiction of Canadian writers since the 1970s.

ARTS-5864.courseDescription: is a study of representative Canadian fiction since 1930, including such authors as Ross, Buckler, Davies, Laurence, Atwood, Ondaatje and Findley.

ARTS-5900.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5900.courseDescription: offers a broad overview of post-colonial studies in English. The course provides an introduction to key ideas in the field and a study of representative texts.
ARTS-5900.courseTitle: Empire and After: Introduction to Post-Colonial Writing

ARTS-5901.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5901.courseDescription: focuses on contemporary writing by established Australian authors. It pays particular attention to the after effects of colonialism and the formulation of national identities.

ARTS-5903.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5903.courseDescription: focuses on major Irish poets, mainly of the twentieth century.

ARTS-5905.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5905.courseDescription: focuses on major Irish writers in at least two genres.

ARTS-5906.courseTitle: Drama of the Restoration and Eighteenth Century

ARTS-5907.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5907.courseDescription: is a study of representative Scottish poetry and prose from the eighteenth to the twenty-first century including selected works by such writers as Boswell, Burns, Hogg, Scott, Stevenson, Spark, and Rankin.

ARTS-5908.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5908.courseDescription: is a study of tragedies and romances such as

ARTS-5909.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5909.courseDescription: is a study of comedies and histories such as

ARTS-5959.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5959.courseDescription: is a course on representative fiction, prose and poetry, including works by such authors as Edwards, Cooper, Hawthorne, Melville, Thoreau, Emerson, Poe, Whitman and Dickinson.

ARTS-5878.courseDescription: introduces the literary sub-genres of science fiction and fantasy. It examines the traditional canonical backgrounds from which popular literatures derive, studies the formulaic patterns and explores the place of science fiction and fantasy in popular culture.

ARTS-5879.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.

ARTS-5874.courseTitle: History of the English Language from 1500 to Modern Times

ARTS-5875.courseDescription: is a study of the language and literature of the later medieval period, excluding Chaucer.

ARTS-5870.courseDescription: is a study of representative American fiction of the nineteenth century including works by such authors as Poe, Hawthorne, Melville, Stowe, Twain and Chopin. Some sections of this course may qualify as Research/Writing courses for the B.A.

ARTS-5872.courseDescription: is a practical introduction to the descriptive study of the English language with emphasis on syntax.

ARTS-5873.courseTitle: History of the English Language to 1500

ARTS-5975.PR: two 3000-level English courses. ENGL 2600 or 3600 is recommended.
ARTS-5975.courseDescription: is an in-depth study of some of the major writers of the fourteenth century.

ARTS-5976.PR: successful completion of two 3000-level English courses
ARTS-5976.courseDescription: is a study of representative texts of the medieval romance genre from the twelfth to the fifteenth century.

ARTS-5971.PR: ENGL 4420 and successful completion of two third-year English courses

ARTS-5973.PR: ENGL 3500 and one other 3000-level English course
ARTS-5973.courseDescription: is a detailed study of one or more major texts in Old English, depending on student interest.
ARTS-5973.courseTitle: Advanced Old English Language and Literature

ARTS-5851.courseDescription: is a survey of drama from the Greeks to the present day. Some sections of this course may qualify as Research/Writing courses for the B.A.

ARTS-5979.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5979.courseDescription: will have topics to be studied announced by the Department.

ARTS-7301.courseDescription: introduces students to the field of visual culture and familiarizes them with both the vocabulary and the methodologies to examine images critically.

ARTS-7303.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-7303.courseDescription: will examine the development of science fiction from its beginnings to the present day. It will consider some of the major authors, theories, forms and concerns that have been the focus of the genre.
ARTS-7303.courseTitle: Science Fiction - The Golden Age and Beyond

ARTS-5881.courseDescription: is designed to introduce students to the medium of film. It is aimed at marking a shift from the natural enjoyment of movies to a critical understanding and to modes of film practice. Focus will be on the elements of film as components of cinematic style and meaning and on various approaches to the study of film.

ARTS-5880.courseDescription: is an introduction to the study of contemporary theory and criticism with an emphasis on its application in the reading of literary texts.
ARTS-5880.courseTitle: Introduction to Literary Theory and Criticism

ARTS-5883.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5883.courseDescription: is a study of satire from classical times, examining major forms of satiric expression such as the monologue, the parody and the long narrative.

ARTS-5882.courseDescription: is concerned with developing visual literacy skills, while also providing terminology and theory necessary to critically engage film. Special attention is paid to film form, historical/social contexts for the production and reception of visual images, and the roles that progressive reproduction technologies, spectatorship, and seeing play in understanding our contemporary world through and beyond visual culture.
ARTS-5882.courseTitle: Introduction to Film Form and Film Theory

ARTS-5887.courseDescription: is a study of the development of pre-Shakespearean drama, including representative cycle plays, morality plays, moral interludes, comedies, tragedies, folk plays, and royal entries.

ARTS-5886.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5886.courseTitle: Women Writers of the Middle Ages

ARTS-5889.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5889.courseDescription: explores in detail a wide range of poetry, using one or more of a variety of methods, contemporary and traditional, designed to lead an understanding of the thematic and technical of individual poems.

ARTS-5888.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5888.courseDescription: is a study of the development of English drama (excluding Shakespeare) from 1580 to 1642.

ARTS-5966.PR: ENGL 3350 and 3351 or permission of the instructor, in consultation with the Head of the Department
ARTS-5966.courseDescription: is the analysis, production plans and execution of selected projects.

ARTS-5967.PR: ENGL 3350 and 3351 or permission of the instructor, in consultation with the Head of the Department
ARTS-5967.courseDescription: is a full semester working with a selected play, to culminate in public performance. Students will be required to participate fully in all aspects of the production, except direction, which will be the responsibility of the instructor.

ARTS-5964.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5964.courseDescription: examines representative twentieth-century plays from the traditions of expressionism, surrealism, and the theatre of the absurd.

ARTS-5965.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5965.courseDescription: is a study of representative dramatic works of contemporary British drama.

ARTS-5962.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5962.courseDescription: is a study of representative writers of the period, such as Stevens, Lowell, Wilbur, Plath, McCullers, Bellow, Malamud.
ARTS-5962.CR: credit may be obtained for only three of ENGL 3215 , 4260 , 4261 , and 4270

ARTS-5963.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5963.courseDescription: examines representative plays from Ibsen to the present day, principally of the realist tradition.

ARTS-5960.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5960.courseDescription: traces the development of American literature from the closing of the frontier to the beginning of the Depression through the study of such writers as Adams, James, Crane, Dreiser, Cather, Robinson and Frost.
ARTS-5960.CR: credit may be obtained for only three of ENGL 3215 , 4260, 4261 , and 4270

ARTS-5961.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5961.courseDescription: concentrates on the study of American fiction, drama and poetry in the period between the two World Wars. The course includes such writers as Hemingway, Faulkner, Fitzgerald, O'Neill, Stevens, Cummings and Hart Crane.
ARTS-5961.CR: credit may be obtained for only three of ENGL 3215 , 4260 , 4261, and 4270

ARTS-5968.PR: ENGL 3350 , 3351 , and 3816 . Admission priority will be given to students in the  Diploma in Performance and Communications Media .
ARTS-5968.courseDescription: is a full semester working on a selected project, to culminate in the creation of a completed video. Students, working in groups established by the Program Co-ordinator, will be required to participate in all aspects of production.

ARTS-5928.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5928.courseDescription: offers an introduction to the Gothic mode in a selection of texts from the eighteenth century to the present. Topics covered may include the Gothic’s recurrent themes of sin, sex, violence, and religion; its subversive response to dominant cultures and historical contexts; and its philosophical roots in sensibility, horror, and the sublime.

ARTS-5893.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5893.courseDescription: is a study of eighteenth-century English novels by such authors as Burney, Defoe, Fielding, Manley, Richardson, Sterne and Smollett.

ARTS-5890.courseTitle: Issues in the Acquisition of English and the Adult Learner

ARTS-5846.courseDescription: is a study of drama. Emphasis is place on critical reading and writing: analysing texts, framing and using questions, constructing essays, organizing paragraphs, conducting research, quoting and documenting, revising and editing.
ARTS-5846.CR: Students may not receive credit for more than 6 credit hours in first-year courses in English (this includes unspecified first-year transfer credits).
ARTS-5846.UL: may not be used instead of ENGL 2002 as a prerequisite for entry into the Theatre-Drama specialization within the Major.

ARTS-5896.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5896.courseDescription: is a study of Newfoundland literature with emphasis on representative writers since 1900.

ARTS-5897.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5897.courseDescription: Drama is a study of a number of representative plays which illustrate the development of modern drama and theatre in Canada.

ARTS-5894.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5894.courseDescription: is a study of the development of Canadian literature from its beginnings to the end of World War I.

ARTS-5953.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5953.courseDescription: is a study of representative texts from 1920-1945 in their social, historical, and cultural contexts.

ARTS-5952.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5952.courseDescription: is a study of late nineteenth- and early twentieth-century texts in their social, historical, and cultural contexts.

ARTS-5898.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5898.courseDescription: is a study of the development of Canadian literature from 1945 to 1970.
ARTS-5898.CR: ENGL 3148 , the former ENGL 3146, the former ENGL 3151, the former ENGL 3154

ARTS-5899.PR: successful completion of two second-year English courses
ARTS-5899.courseDescription: is a study of recent developments in Canadian literature.
ARTS-5899.CR: ENGL 3148 , the former ENGL 3146, the former ENGL 3151, the former ENGL 3154

ARTS-5957.courseDescription: is an advanced course focusing on such plays as

ARTS-5956.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5956.courseDescription: is a survey of critical approaches to literature in the twentieth century. Students are advised to take this course towards the end of their program.

ARTS-5955.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5955.courseDescription: is a survey of critical approaches to literature, from Plato to the end of the nineteenth century. Students are advised to take this course towards the end of their program.

ARTS-5954.PR: successful completion of two third-year English courses
ARTS-5954.courseDescription: is a study of representative texts from World War II to the present in their social, historical, and cultural contexts.
